q: 1) Why do certain letters like A, C, and G survive mode collapse while others like Q, X, and Z do not?
options: A) Because A, C, and G have sharper edges that make them easier to learn.
B) Because they appear more often in the dataset being used for training.

q: 2) How does feature-matching compare to vanilla GAN in terms of letter diversity after a fix is applied?
options: A) It shows improved letter diversity compared to the vanilla GAN baseline.
B) It maintains the same level of letter diversity as the vanilla GAN.

q: 3) What conclusion can be drawn from visual quality assessment results regarding feature-matching’s performance on letter shapes?
options: A) Feature-matching produces more recognizable letter shapes compared to vanilla GAN.
B) Feature-matching fails to produce any recognizable letter shapes.
